title: On 29 June 2018, how many public hydrogen fueling stations will be available in the United States?
preds:
It  seems that the public are slow to realise the benefits of  a 'hydrogen economy'
(i)  They seem to be 'decoyed' by  battery power and hybrids etc
(ii) They seem to confuse 'power generation' and 'storage' Mr. Average has not been adequately educated  on  safe storage of hydrogen and benefits such as rapid refuelling etc. Looking ahead - say over 10 years, we can surmise -
- all new cars will be electrically powered
-  internal combusion engines will gradually  decline- as hybrids outlive their utility One wonders how the oil industry will take this ?   One wonders how Governments will react to this - particularly the governments of the major oil producing nations Within 50 years fusion energy will dominate - but can anyone imagine the turmoil that this will cause in terms of changes in  geopolitical power  The hydrogen fuel cell is so elegant - one hydrogen atom  converts to the flow of one electron !
However-   Power and politics will prevail in the short-medium term!
As of 11 June, there are only 35 hyrdrogen fueling stations in the United States.
Going 100 to under 45 because there's only a month left and I don't see much rapid growth happening.
WoC0.89  Will be crazy if it somehow jumped by 12 in 4 weeks. Not impossible but highly unlikely. Would be some weird admin error.
We lost one in the past month? Down to 40, including non-retail.

The most recent data as of May 18, 2018 shows 34 current retail fueling stations available. The additional 12 stations in the northeast are not expected to open for sometime. Reports as of May 18, 2017 said that the first station would be open by the end of 2017, but the data from the AFDC shows no stations yet open in the Northeast. This leads me to believe this project is going slower than the originally projected timeline and will not be able to boost the number of stations over 45 before June 2018. The additional California stations mentioned seem to be opening slowly as well. On May 18th last year there were 30 and now currently are 34. At that rate, it is unlikely the number of stations will exceed 45 before 29 June, 2018.

Someone mentioned the recent drop from 42 to 40.  These 2 were definitely California sites, but I couldn't figure out which.  I tried to use the Wayback machine to look at previous versions of the map, and it worked last time I did it, but this time it did not work.  Regardless, I highly doubt we will reach 45, but, I am already at 99%, have no idea why the 2 disappeared (which means they could re-appear just as easy), so I am leaving as is.
Edit:  One of the ones that disappeared was Palo Alto, which was also one of the most recent to be added. Edit:  Re-found the info from California's website, which has now been updated as of the 11th of May.   https://cafcp.org/sites/default/files/h2_station_list.pdf The totals equal the federal website, except for one discrepency (Cal State), which is listed as "commissioning" on the Cal site.  There are two sites that are still possible in california that could be completed before July, Woodside and Burbank.  That would bring the total to 42.  So at least 3 of the 4 sites on the east coast would need to open.  I doubt this will happen, although my Aire Liquid contact was still vague upon last email when she stated, "Hi Greg, The three sites were completed in the first quarter. They are not yet open to the public for use as we will open them officially with the launch of the vehicles. The app is scheduled to launch end of May!" I asked her to explain the launch of the vehicles and timeframe, and she replied with, "That, I would have to defer to Toyota on. I believe they are looking at the summer time, but I can certainly get a better time frame."   So I am currently waiting on her to get a reply from Toyota, but I am not as confident I will get an answer, as it requires someone else answering her.  I have a little concern that Summer is a vague answer, and this may possibly also mean June.  But, given the way all these questions seem to work, everything usually happens slower, not quicker, than I think it will.  So I will leave the 1%, just in case, as it would require a combination of the east coast sites AND at least one Cal site to come online.
Website's still at 40, which makes it seem more than a bug.
The total now reads 40 for some reason instead of 42 as it did before. HT @Mr_Burns.
Website is janky.   The total is now at 40 instead of 42.  Similarly, the DC fast charge has been stuck on 2302 for almost three weeks.

I’m sure  @Nugdunk at al have seen similar articles. Seems Air Liquide is almost as good at expectations as Elon Musk. Saw several articles mentioning a dozen stations in NE USA by now... what’s interesting is this article also impacts the Mirai forecast. @Nugdunk may be correct - they may sneak a few in just to wreck our brier score (still mad at Duterte withdrawing from ICC!). Sacre bleu!
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-07-24/toyota-s-hydrogen-holdup-means-new-englanders-miss-out-on-mirai
Re-balancing from my answer yesterday because I didn't realize I had to include non-retail stations and the real total is 42, not 34.
We are up to 34 and given the incredibly slow rate of growth I don't see any way to get to 45 by the end of next month.
Lowering on new sites that have been built and may become public (thereby entering into the total count) as per the helpful research by @Nugdunk

Received another email from Air Liquide: "The three sites were completed in the first quarter. They are not yet open to the public for use as we will open them officially with the launch of the vehicles. The app is scheduled to launch end of May!" (they are building their own locator app) So three of the sites that were under construction were completed, but it is unclear what the "launch of the vehicles" actually is.  I posed another question regarding the vehicle launch yesterday and have yet to receive a reply.  I will post if and when I get the reply.  But the timeline to "launch", then to actually get on the AFDC website appears pretty slim.  But, if it does, those three bring us to 45, and my brier score goes down.
There are reportedly 33 at present. With less than two months left before the cut off of this question, it is highly unlikely that another 50% of the existing number could be built.
Still sitting at 42. 7 weeks to go. Adding 1 every couple weeks would be abnormally high.

The last two added over the past month, bringing the total to 42, were 2 of the 4 listed as "highly likely" and possible.   https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/705890 From that list, I still have "Orange, CA" and "Woodside" still left as possibilities, which would bring the total to 44, and I believe that to be accurate for California.  The issue I run into is the gray are of the east coast sites and Aire Liquid.  Below is the email I received after inquiry.  Note that it states "will complete in the first quarter", and I received the email in March, not giving them much time.  I replied to the email today to get an update. "Thanks for contacting us via our website and for your interest in they hydrogen energy infrastructure in the northeast. 
In regards to the hydrogen stations in the northeast, three will be completed in the first quarter of this year. We do not have exact or updated dates and timelines for the others, but will provide them to you once received. Please note that while the stations will be completed and open, the status and availability of the stations to the public will vary by location and vehicles in the market. 
Lastly, all stations will be managed and updated in the new hydrogen station finder app that we will be launching in the next couple of months. As for the afdc.energy.gov website, that I am not too sure about."
42 as of 04.29. Will 3 come online in a month - would be faster than normal pace but never know how many near completion.

According to this chart (https://www.afdc.energy.gov/data/10332) all hydrogen stations grew from 7 in 2002 to 63 in 2009 (I assume they count non-public stations). From 2009, stations actually declined to 39 in 2015 (and have since increased since then). Electric recharging stations have grown from 873 in 2002 to 42,011 in 2016. Regulated fleets have acquired minimal hydrogen vehicles (maximum 9 per annum) compared to max 595 per annum for electric vehicles and 20,623 for E85 fueled vehicles (https://www.afdc.energy.gov/data/10354). Given this, I believe it's quite possible the nubmer of stations might drop.
Up to 42.  Looks like one in Los Angeles opened judging by the map

There were 39 in late January. 2 more have since opened in California, one in Mountain View, and the other in Thousand Oaks. https://cafcp.org/sites/default/files/h2_station_list.pdf. 2 more in California are currently undergoing commissioning, the final stage, which can take weeks to months, but it is possible they will open before the end of June. The additional 12 planned in the Northeast are not scheduled to open until 3-4Q 2018. https://morningconsult.com/2018/03/29/hydrogen-cars-arent-the-hindenburg-and-other-marketing-hurdles-for-toyotas-mirai/. There is an additional station in Hempstead, NY, that is not counted for unknown reasons, that is or soon will be under renovation. https://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/point-lookout-hydrogen-1.16496819. Total count: 41 - 42.
They are expensive to build 1-5 million require real engineering. Require permits.
There are currently 39. 50 were supposed to be online by 2017.
I checked the data on the map and analysis provided.

Disagree with the clarification: public connotes that anyone wanting to fill up can do so. The non-retails are not public, you can't use them. You need to be a member or registered with them and or have some training on how to use the nozzle etc. No matter how hard you try, at the universities even if you're a final year 4.0 GPA student or professor emeritus bribing to be let in the locked area to fill your Mirai you're not going to get your H2- some of these places don't even accept payment, they're on an expense account system.  But whatever. Hopefully it still stays under 45, obviously my bias, though I look forward to seeing more FCV and H2 nozzles throughout the world.

True retail demand is not where it needs to be in order to have any confidence that an additional 5 or 6 HF Stations will come online in the next 90 days.  Retailers & other organizations have been very slow at building this infrastructure, If you notice this has been in the works now for several years and they only show about 40 stations open.
With less than 90 days, and only 41 showing, including non-retail.  The odds are against beating the 45 mark.
it is not far enought in time to think it is profitable for a company compete inthis bussines

Currently 41, including non-retail. Spreadsheet still showing only 39 open stations.
Spreadsheet is showing three planned stations that should have opened by now and 2 more planned for 1 July. Maybe two of those stations have opened and spreadsheet has not updated.

There are 39 in existence as of Jan 25, 2018
Another 34 are planned - this is misleading , for more accurate data see Nugdunk at www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/705890
Looks like up to 7 possible additional stations by mid-year, but only about 3 seem likely - the others are long shots.

85/15/0. I suppose it's possible that another 12 will be finished by the end of June (there are 33 in operation in California only presently) but it seems unlikely. Given the strong momentum behind EV's as a replacement for fossil-fuel driven vehicles, it seems very possible that these 33 will be the only 33. And all it will take will be one Hindenburg-like catastrophe and hydrogen as a fuel source will be done.
Flipping back after the recent clarification.

Only one temporarily offline station has been added to the open list in one month. None of the four stations expected before the deadline (including two scheduled for Jan 1st 2018) have been opened. I'm going with the base rate adjusted using a 50% probability that the expected stations will be completed and opened in time, and a 5% probability that the two stations whose expected dates are just beyond the deadline will open in time. As time goes on, I'll reduce the probability that the expected stations will be completed in time.

There are 39 in existence as of Jan 25, 2018
Another 34 are planned.
Assuming that the planned H2 stations will be built by the end of 2018 (which may be a mistake), we can expect half that number to be built before the halfway point of 2018.
That would add 17 new stations to the existing for a total of 56.
California is has always been a leader that pushes the boundaries with environment issues and they are planned 29 stations, so my guess is that they will see this through more so than other states.
So as a minimum, I would expect at least half of California's planned stations to be in existence by mid 2018 bringing the total to approximately 53.

I am assuming ONLY retail stations will be counted, because the word PUBLIC appears in the question.
Given that there are only about 32 today fewer than 45 seems prudent.
33 pre-existing/underway in CA. Likelihood that hydrogen makes continued gains on the back of EV isn't far fetched. That's just 13 more stations nationwide to account for.

An update to my last forecast misunderstanding the public/private distinction. With only 32 current stations and knowing how complex an ultra high pressure hydrogen system is to certify for operation, I doubt that anything built this year will be open to the public by June 29.
Slow pace in North East means CA is primary determimant.
There were 54 already in 2016 according to DoE. Not sure why AFDC is different, didn't notice before answering.

Just wanted to remind everyone that there is a clarification pending for this question.  Recently, due to changes to the website, the number dropped from 40 to 32 due to the fact that you now have to check a box for "include non retail stations".  The question does not state whether or not "non retail is included", but everyone's forecasts were including those additional 8 originally.  I requested clarification when the website changed, but have not yet received a reply.  If the ruling comes back that those do not count, it will positively be below 45 on July 1st. Also, I am not sure if I posted this previously, but I received a response from Air Liquide a while back regarding sites on the east coast, and the rep stated, "Thanks for contacting us via our website and for your interest in they hydrogen energy infrastructure in the northeast.  In regards to the hydrogen stations in the northeast, three will be completed in the first quarter of this year.We do not have exact or updated dates and timelines for the others, but will provide them to you once received. Please note that while the stations will be completed and open, the status and availability of the stations to the public will vary by location and vehicles in the market.  Lastly, all stations will be managed and updated in the new hydrogen station finder app that we will be launching in the next couple of months. As for the afdc.energy.gov website, that I am not too sure about."
Upcoming battery technology will make hyfrogen fuel cells economically inpractical.

There are currently 32 hydrogen stations in the United States, the cost of building a station remains high while onsite electrolysis is expected to have the lowest overall cost for production, it is likely that truck delivery will remain the top method for distribution due to complications created new technology, permits and licensing for onsite production. The legal & safety aspects need to be hammered out then proven before larger fueling companies will risk investment. That is being done ins SOCAL, but frankly I don't see anyone pouring money into it until legal and safety concerns are solid.
Price of gas is not high enough yet for this to grow that fast.

32 stations currently operational. CARB permitting process to set up new H fueling station takes 6 to 18 months. Hydrogen operated engines are not standard consumer products and CARB community has made statements about concerns around safety of operating these engines - therefore growth in engines consuming this fuel will be slow, therefore, it is unlikely that more than 13 additional fueling stations will be built between now and end of June. CARB = California Air Resources Board, the regulatory body (among others) that California gas station operations must get approval from and the one which approval takes longest. H fueling pumps in California are part of normally licensed gas stations. Gas stations apply for approvals to operate an H pump and turnaround time for processing takes months. The queue for opening gas station or extending existing station to include an H pump in addition to existing normal gasoline pumps seems to be same (same forms).

Counted 31 on here https://ssl.toyota.com/mirai/stations.html  It's unreliable and out of date because it has opening 'early 2018' still. Maybe @Nugdunk can cross-ref this map with the 40 public and private stations listed in the excel spreadsheet download from the AFDC site.  I've added my email address to be alerted when Thousand Oaks, Ontario etc open.  There are over 20 opening in 2019. So it would be great to see this question repeated for a new timeline.
Hydrogen is not high on the public awareness of alternative fuels.  Storage is a key issue

I received some replies and had phone communication with involving a couple of different sites.   Woodside, CA - This is one of the potential 4 in California that could have made the July 1st cutoff.  I emailed yesterday, and received a call today from a city employee.  He stated that the permits were recently given, so the construction could start any time.  It did not sound as if it was even close to being near completion, so I am taking this one off my list of possibilities.   Thousand Oaks site - Received a reply stating, "I believe they have all their approvals so construction is in their court. I’ve CC’d a couple folks from our Community Development Department who may have more detail or a contact with the station."  This gives me the hunch that they aren't anywhere near completion, but I want to confirm, so hopefully the folks cc'd on the email will get a hold of me. East Coast - (Air Liquide) - in a reply, stated, "Thanks for contacting us via our website and for your interest in they hydrogen energy infrastructure in the northeast.  In regards to the hydrogen stations in the northeast, three will be completed in the first quarter of this year.We do not have exact or updated dates and timelines for the others, but will provide them to you once received. Please note that while the stations will be completed and open, the status and availability of the stations to the public will vary by location and vehicles in the market.  Lastly, all stations will be managed and updated in the new hydrogen station finder app that we will be launching in the next couple of months. As for the afdc.energy.gov website, that I am not too sure about."  So I am not sure about how soon the ones that "will be completed in the first quarter" will be done, or if it is one that is already on the list.  What concerned me more was that, from the comment, there doesn't appear to be any connection between AFDC and the companies building these sites.  So even if a site is up and running, will it be on AFDC's website?  Its tough to say.  I am going to continue to talk to these folks to hopefully get better answers.  This is a question that we should be able to say with 90+ percent accuracy exactly how many stations will be listed on July 1st.  It will just take talking to the right people.   Based on the belief that the two California sites are less likely than I thought before, I am going +2 to Fewer than 45.  But, I have concern with the east coast, so hopefully i will find out more information soon, and that may move the needle considerably back over 45.

In my previous forecasts I found that there are 4 sites in california that could potentially be completed by July 1st. 
 One of them is the Thousand Oaks, CA site.  I just found the city government meeting minutes in which they are requesting some construction permits.  It does not give me a strong feeling that this one will be completed within the next few months, given the length of time of the commissioning process. 
 I also emailed the city government for an update.  On that note, I also sent messages to the Ontario, CA and Woodside CA sites to find out more info.  I will place any replies on my next forecast. 
  http://www.toaks.org/home/showdocument?id=66

No update to the forecast, but noted that the website has been updated and the map now defaults to NOT include the non retail sites.  This brings the number down from 40 to 36.  The problem is, the additional 4 used to be included automatically, and now you have to check a box to place them on the map.  I asked for a clarification if the  non-retail sites were included or not, as the map states, "public sites", and has the "non-retail" checkbox within it, so I am assuming they should be included.
It is unlikely many stations will be built.
Despite widespread investment, hydrogen fuelling will be limited to cities where car owners can afford to buy new cars with the fuel cells

CNG vehicles are no longer offered.;Honda ceased production..Toyota is pushing hard and offering free hydrogen fill-ups for a period of time. The only alternative is gas-hybrid-plugin or just plug-in. Hydrogen will be the only fuel for long range travel (300miles) Gasoline will be phased out in 20 year followed up by diesel in the U.S killing the Russian and Middle East economies at the same time.
There has not exactly been a stampede to make this happen, nor is one likely to appear.

This is odd. AFDC has redesigned its widget and it's showing fewer stations. I believe it was showing 40 completed and 76 total (completed + planned). Now I'm seeing 32 completed and  59 total. (Mystery solved: I need to include non-retail stations, which brings it to 40.) Looking at the downloadable spreadsheet, it's showing 39 currently open and only 2 planned to open before end of June (though 2 are planned for 1 July). The last spreadsheet I looked at showed 9 planned to open before July.

ccording to US government, there are already 60... https://www.hydrogen.energy.gov/permitting/stations_studies.cfm According to this: dated 2016 https://www.energy.gov/sites/prod/files/2016/11/f34/fcto_state_of_states_2016.pdf California: "nearly 50" 
Colorado: 2 
Connecticut: 1 
Massachussetts: 2 
NY: 1 https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hydrogen-stations-move-forward-in-brooklyn-and-the_us_5989ecb5e4b08a4c247f25fd
Lists 4 sites opened. This site lists Air liquides contacts and phone numbers if one really wanted to find the number of stations up to date. https://industry.airliquide.us/air-liquide-ready-build-hydrogen-station-network-new-york https://cafcp.org/stationmap
Lists 36 with only 4 in construction or commissioning another 15 in planning. I have no idea why the US DOE lists 60. Other interesting links: http://www.ct.gov/deep/lib/deep/air/electric_vehicle/evct/2018-01-31_-_Hydrogen_Fueling_Station_Grant_Comments.pdf
Currently there are 40 stations declared, 50 was the number projected for end of 2017.
+2 to fewer than 45.  No updates to either the AFDC site (40), or the California site that has the same status for all of the sites.
40 - Currently concentrated in CA, SC, and the North East.

There are currently 40 stations online with 33 planned.  It's extremely difficult to find the status of the "planned" stations, but if you manipulate the statistics in - and publication dates of - online articles, it extrapolates out to at least 4 more stations should become operational by late June.
If there are going to be an
hydrogen is not the best alternative, especially from a safety point
Only couple of months left to build those stations and only 40 to date!
Swapping due to no public demand on the east coast. If there is no announcements soon (14 days or so) then I'll have to scale it right back to 80-20 and then 99-1 by May.
CURRENTLY 40 OPEN IN US BASED ON D.O.E.,

A new lead perhaps for @Nugdunk? So far, California is the only place in North America where drivers can buy a fuel cell vehicle and have some confidence they can get it refueled. “Competition is pretty scarce right now,” says Shane Stephens, chief development officer of FirstElement Fuel Inc., which built 16 of California’s 31 stations with $28 million in state grants. Most of the existing single-pump stations can fill 50 tanks to 60 tanks a day. Sometimes there’s a wait at the pumps, but mostly the nozzles hang limp, devoid of cars to feed.
On the occasions when two or more cars line up to fill at the same time, the second car typically has to wait an extra few minutes after the first car is done, because gas pumped under high pressure begins to freeze a single pump’s nipple, condensing moisture from the air into ice. Several newer, two-pump stations have helped address this problem, but California still needs more trucks to deliver supplies of hydrogen for the stations. (The state is subsidizing the refills for eight years.)   Previous comment has article link. Interesting to learn that California is the only state hydrogen cars are available for sale. So that puts a wet towel on demand for east coast. Given it's public tanks only.

Just saw this from my daily news alert https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-05/california-should-focus-on-electric-cars-not-hydrogen-fuel (archived at http://archive.is/qY9q7)  Pessimistic take. Says 500 miles and 4 minutes to fill though. True Zero brand at Valero. $45 to fill tank. Does one per hour on a good day.

Slight change in my score, adding 2 to "Between 45 and 55" and subtracting 2 from "Fewer than 45" due to a new document read (1).  Right now, it causes me to question the possibility of all the California sites of making it to completion.  By the timeline provided, it shows everything listed as "commissioning" should be completed by 29 JUN, and even a project in LA in construction phase could make it.  On page 25 of the annual assessment (1) from CAFCP, it shows that there is an average of 261 days from beginning of construction to completion and availability to the public.  The LAX project started in May of 2017, So it is already beyond this point but still listed as "under construction"(2).   The same document(1) shows that organizations with construction completed should only have about 66 days to when the site is open to the public.  It is unclear though if the three sites listed as "commissioning"(2) are actually considered in "Phase 4", (the 66 day phase).  Phase 3 is described as, "This phase includes station construction and meeting operational requirements: the station has a hydrogen fuel supply, passes a hydrogen quality test, dispenses at the H70-T40 pressure and temperature per standard (SAE J2601), successfully fuels one FCEV, and receives the occupancy permit from the AHJ."   So overall, it appears the three California sites listed as "commissioning" should get completed, giving a total of 43.  I am not more confident that other sites will be completed on the west coast, but I have no more information for the east coast sites.  (1) http://www.energy.ca.gov/2017publications/CEC-600-2017-011/CEC-600-2017-011.pdf (primarily pages 25-26)
(2) https://cafcp.org/sites/default/files/h2_station_list.pdf

I have received replies to questions for more information from both AFDC and California's CAFCP.  I have not received any replies from Air Liquide, the company primarily on the east coast, so the only information I have to update you with is for the California area.   To summarize, there are currently 40 listed on the AFDC website.  There is a discrepency with one (Cal State LA).  AFDC states its open, CAFCP states it is "Under review" in the "Commissioning Phase".  I asked how many of the "commissioning phase" (there are 4 including Cal State) that they thought would be completed by July.  The person replying stated that she would not give an estimate, as the process can take a long time.   Of these that are commissioning, their projected completion date was or is:
AFDC/CAFCP
Cal State: *** completed/under review discrepency
Ontario: 1 January/Early Spring
Woodside: 1 Jul/Early Spring
Thousand Oaks: 1 Jul/Early Spring
One other California site is scheduled to be completed by 1 JUL, but CAFCP still has them listed in the Planning (pre-construction) phase.  A note in another category leads me to believe the building process can take up to a year, so I doubt this one has an opportunity to be completed.   The above 3 (Ontario, Woodside, Thousand Oaks) are the best bet for completion in California, and there is a very slight chance that Cal State, which is on the list could potentially be removed (Very small).  So ultimately, at best, California can get +3 sites for a total of 43 sites.  Worst case scenario, they drop by 1 to 39, as no new sites are added and the Cal State site is removed.  This is highly unlikely, and my best guess is that the Ontario site is added while the other two do not make their 1 JUL milestone.   There are others we can see on the AFDC site that aren't listed on the CAFCP site, which is confusing, as you would think CAFCP would have a better idea of sites in California.  For example, AFDC has a site in Orange, CA, which is not listed on the CAFCP site.  It is showing last updated in early December, so maybe its been cancelled since? When I contact them again, I will ask.   There are only 2 on the east coast scheduled to be completed by the end date of this competition, 29 JUN.  One in Providence, RI (1 JAN), and 1 in Harford, CT (1 MAR).  I have no idea of the status of these, but will continue to work on it.  If my projection is correct, and only 1 of the three are completed in Cali, the east coast really doesn't matter.  If all three in Cali are completed, the both of these east coast projects have to be completed also.  This hits 45, the absolute minimum for the next category up.  This does not factor in the Orange, CA anomoly that is only listed on the Federal site, which, could add one more as it was scheduled for 1 MAR.   To  summarize, with apologies for redundancy:
7 possibilities for completion, and my thoughts:
Ontario - CA: Past completion date, in "commission" Phase: Likely
Providence, RI: Unknown
Orange, CA: Anomaly, not on California list but 1 MAR completion date on Fed: Possible
Hartford, CT: Unknown
Palo Alto, CA: Completion date 1 JUL, listed in planning phase currently: Highly unlikely
Thousand Oaks, CA: Completion date 1 Jul, Commissioning Phase: Possible
Woodside, CA: Completion date 1 JUL, Comissioning Phase: Possible
25 Others listed as planned: Completion dates starting in December 18: Highly unlikely As a result, it would require 5 of the 6 of that I rated higher than "unlikely"; likely (1), unknown (2), and possible (3) to be completed and added.  I don't like the odds for all of 5-6 of these projects being completed, so as a result, I am going to significantly increase my Fewer than 45 by 25 points, reduce between 45 and 55 by 24 points, and reduce more than 55 by 1, giving it no chance.

Having received replies and initially looking at the data sent back from some of the organizations related to these projects, I have noted that more than 55 is not likely.  I can see why the question really focuses around the 45 number, and I think it will be easier, once I look over the information to discern which of the two should receive a higher percentage in the under over 45.  I will share my analysis, where I got it from, and hopefully post the raw data also if it doesn't take up too much space in a reply.  I will attempt to get it done by 8:00 PM Pacific.  Posted this just in case I am unable to get it done until tomorrow and don't end up updating my forecast. Wanted to reduce the over 55 possibility. Reduced the over 55 by 3 points down to 1% and added 2% to over 45, 1% to under 45%
Some already exist the likely hood of that amount really should increase with time.
Environmental impact studies associated with new fueling stations are long and drawn out + your standard bureaucracy= redtape.
Accroindg toAFDC there are 64 hydrogen stations, 40 public and 24 public. The article mentions that there are expected to be more than 50 in the USA by the end of 2017.

Becoming much more an information gathering exercise. Not sure the time invested for me is worth it, so just throwing a dampener on my first numbers as it was a bit too optimistic.  The govt site requires a name and email address to access the data. No thanks, what BS is this? So if anyone gets it can they link it? Liberate the data! The energy.gov site is utter crap.  There are 3 tractors, 2 shuttle buses and a van. No cars etc. So it doesn't appear to be much demand to the public. https://www.afdc.energy.gov/vehicles/search/compare?&current=true&display_length=100&fuel_id=9,-1&all_manufacturers=y&ids=10036,10455,10453,10393,10394&page_type=engine  Air Liquide claim fill up is 5 minutes for up to 500 miles but the DoE says 10 minutes for 300 miles. By the end of 2017, there are expected to be more than 50 retail stations available nationwide, although most are concentrated in California. In addition to the retail stations available for all FCEVs, there are also stations supporting fleets and some primarily used for demonstration and/or research. As the demand for FCEVs grows, the business case for building more stations with higher capacities improves and the volume in production of station components will bring station costs down.
https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_stations.html

You can download the data from the AFDC site on current and planned stations.  Of the planned stations, 3 are already overdue for opening, multiple other stations are planned for early 2018 openings.  While they will all likely remain behind schedule, still a good chance that at least 5 of them will open before the end of June.  Data on the AFDC site is updated monthly - last update was 3/3/2018.

Given the 40 now operational and knowing that this is more of an 'west coast - east coast' development, it appears that a very slow growth is occurring.  Station cost seems not to be the issue; public acceptance, the willingness to purchase these vehicles and being constrained by geographical location of stations seem to be the constraining factors.

Good engineering reasons why H2 is unlikely to be fuel for the road.

Hydrogen is the fuel currency of the future and will displace batteries. However, there has been over a century of electric power distribution infrastructure development. Hydrogen distribution has a much shorter development time.

Harder to store but more efficient, hydrogen has many advantages over stored electricity. Smaller volume/longer range, and the ability to refuel if stuck in the desert. Big Rigs and buses will be the first to transition, since it makes economic sense, and isn't just "cool".

We're already at 40, and a series of tax breaks, tax laws, and statutory laws incentivize the public construction of hydrogen fueling stations before 2019.    https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/laws/HY/US

This looks like it is going to be a hard one as there have been multiple rate changes since construction of the stations started. A look at the raw data provided by the AFDC (as of March 2nd) shows that there are 40 stations opened and a very large number of stations planned, but most of the latter have an expected completion date of Jan 1st 2019, giving no indication of how many of these are actually underway. I'm working on a two-model plan, taking the average of the two for now : 
1) use the base-rate of the past two years (since the last significant rate-hike) : 16 stations / 600 days
2) assume 80% of the stations indicated as 'late' by the AFDC data will be completed by the deadline, and 20% of the other planned stations will also be completed. Model 1 gives : 78% / 22% / 0%
Model 2 gives : 0% / 90% / 10%  That model 2 gives so many more stations than model 1 indicates that the desire to open new stations exceeds the past capacity for building and opening them (of course, more ressources could be put into building stations in 2018 than before). The average of the two models gives the probabilities forecast above.
Certainly enough planned for to excede 55, but it’s not apparent if they are in work.
Going very low due to the slow rate of growth of public hydrogen fueling stations.

There were 34 hydrogen fueling stations in the US in April 2017 (https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/california/articles/2017-04-13/hydrogen-fuel-cell-cars-creep-up-slowly-on-electrics) and according to the Alternative Fuels Data Center there are 40 now (https://www.afdc.energy.gov/fuels/hydrogen_locations.html). Low chance that the rate of new stations has increased enough to open >1/month from now until June.
There's not a huge market for this, and thus not major incentive to build this stations rapidly.

Based on the articles above, it looks like almost 2 stations have been build in California per month since March 2017. I'm assuming Honda built these, which means they still have not met their goal of building 36 stations by 2018 so I would expect that they will keep up this trend if not accelerate it to meet their goal. That makes it pretty close, assuming no new stations are being built by anyone else in the next few months. There are 40 stations nationwide now. I'm assigning a slightly higher than 50% chance that this will happen, to account for the possibility that someone will build at least one station elsewhere in that time.
There are currently 39 stations in the US.  It seems unlikely that more than 1 per month will be built within the remaining time.
